text:
Hours before an explosive blowup in the Oval Office between President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Trump and his team felt they had found a path forward to match the presidentâ€™s urgency to end the war with the Ukrainiansâ€™ need for continued security assistance. The East Room of the White House had been decorated in greenery and four pairs of American and Ukrainian flags, set up for the leaders to sign a minerals deal that national security adviser Michael Waltz called â€œcriticalâ€ for the United States. Elsewhere, White House staff were preparing a celebratory lunch of rosemary roasted chicken and crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, with the menu laid out on stationery bearing closely intertwined American and Ukrainian flags.

White House officials were expecting a positive meeting and said they had little reason to anticipate animosity. Both sides were satisfied with the minerals deal, hoping it might recalibrate the relationship between the two nations, Ukrainian and U.S. officials said, speaking like others on condition of anonymity to discuss relations at a tense time. Trump himself was in an upbeat mood the night before the meeting, according to those who had spoken with him.

Advertisement

But what unfolded Friday afternoon was not the coda that was expected on a week that featured relatively chummy and flattery-filled visits from two other transatlantic leaders who sought to shore up Trumpâ€™s support for Kyiv on the third anniversary of the war in Ukraine.

Instead, the ensuing public castigation of Zelensky by Trump and Vice President JD Vance laid bare the deepening rift between Europe and the Trump administration and Republican Party, jeopardizing U.S. aid for Ukraine, the end of war in Europe, and the prospect of a renewed relationship between the two leaders.

Beneath the surface, feelings of hopeful progress were the matchsticks that fueled the explosive meeting: long-standing Republican gripes over a perceived lack of respect by Zelensky and the short-term memory of a meeting in Munich last month between Zelensky, Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

Advertisement

Zelenskyâ€™s popularity within the Republican Party has spiraled since 2023, with Vance emerging as one of the loudest voices advocating to cut off U.S. funding to what heâ€™s called a â€œnever-ending war.â€ Trump last month called Zelensky â€œa dictatorâ€ who wanted to â€œto keep the gravy train goingâ€ at the expense of the United States, and falsely claimed that Ukraine had started the war. But GOP praise for Trump and Vanceâ€™s attack on the Ukrainian leader over the weekend was the most united front against the beleaguered country to date.

The visit also came as the United States sided with Russia and against Ukraine and Europe at the United Nations, voting with other Moscow-aligned countries against a resolution condemning Russian aggression in Ukraine and calling for the return of Ukrainian territory. Earlier in the week, French and British leaders avoided acrimony during White House visits and offered their troops on Ukrainian soil to guarantee a peace deal. Trump had spoken by phone Thursday with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, who emphasized that any deal would need to be â€œenduring,â€ according to NATO.

Friday marked Zelenskyâ€™s fifth visit to the White House, and started like many of the others. His black SUV went through the White House gates, with service members lining the walkway with 58 flags â€” 56 to mark all the states and territories, along with an American flag and a Ukrainian flag.

Advertisement

The first sign of problems to come appeared shortly thereafter: After Zelensky got out of his car in his traditional wartime fatigues, Trump looked at reporters and said, â€œHeâ€™s all dressed up today.â€

It reflected a long-standing complaint that some conservatives have had about the Ukrainian leader, and was resurrected in the Oval Office when Brian Glenn, a correspondent at Real Americaâ€™s Voice and the partner of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Georgia), asked Zelensky, â€œWhy donâ€™t you wear a suit? Youâ€™re at the highest level in this countryâ€™s office, and you refuse to wear a suit.â€

There was tension in the room as the leaders sat down with each other, a senior Trump administration official said. But they still didnâ€™t expect what would happen next, the official said. Trump and Vance both eventually raised their voices to the Ukrainian president, and Zelensky urged them to lower their voices, which only continued in the heated exchange.

Advertisement

Zelensky at one point suggested that he would not accept a ceasefire without a security guarantee, reporters repeatedly pressed Trump on whether the United States would offer any security assurances and the meeting began to unravel when Zelensky chided Vance for commenting on the war without having visited the country.

Vance jumped on Zelenskyâ€™s remark, responding that he knows â€œwhat happens is you bring people on a propaganda tour, Mr. President.â€

Vance had sat through two bilateral Oval Office press gaggles earlier in the week with little interjection, speaking up only when Trump called on him to answer a reporterâ€™s question Thursday during British Prime Minister Keir Starmerâ€™s visit.

But fresh in Vanceâ€™s mind was a meeting only two weeks earlier in Munich, where he, Rubio and Zelensky â€” before aides and cameras joined them â€” had a serious conversation about signing the minerals deal, according to administration officials. The day after the meeting, however, Zelensky said he couldnâ€™t sign a deal that wasnâ€™t connected to security guarantees.

Advertisement

Rubio later said in an interview that Zelensky had assured Vance and himself that he wanted â€œto do this dealâ€ and only needed legislative approval to get it done, and that Zelenskyâ€™s later public comments left the Americans â€œupsetâ€ â€” a sentiment that loomed over Fridayâ€™s Oval Office talks, even as the Trump administration was preparing to make the deal happen.

Vanceâ€™s in-the-moment decision to criticize Zelensky for not being â€œrespectfulâ€ and questioning Trumpâ€™s diplomatic strategy changed the tone of the meeting and primed Trump to also let loose on the Ukrainian president.

â€œDo you think itâ€™s respectful to come into the Oval Office of the United States of America and attack the administration that is trying to prevent the destruction of your country?â€ Vance queried Zelensky.

Seconds later, Trump, who had appeared to be intently listening to Vanceâ€™s scolding of Zelensky, chimed in with his own rebuke: â€œDonâ€™t tell us what weâ€™re going to feel,â€ he interrupted.

Advertisement

Trump and Vance later spoke about the interaction, and Vanceâ€™s decision to chime in, and Trump indicated that he approved of the vice presidentâ€™s comments, according to a White House official.

â€œThey both felt exactly the same way about the circumstances, that Zelensky was being inappropriate,â€ the official said, and that â€œit was not right for him to be litigatingâ€ the U.S. strategy with Russia â€œin front of the press.â€

Vance had said as much to Zelensky in front of the cameras. Trump, for his part, speculated that their exchange would be ratings gold.

â€œThis is going to be great television,â€ Trump declared. â€œI will say that.â€

Once the press was shown out of the Oval Office, so were Zelensky and his delegation. They waited elsewhere in the West Wing as Trump consulted with his advisers about what to do next.

Advertisement

We â€œpretty much unanimously advised the president that after that insult in the Oval Office, we just do not see how that could move forward, that any further engagement would only go backward from this moment on,â€ Waltz told â€œFox News Saturday.â€

It fell to him and Rubio â€” both of them past defenders of Ukraine and Zelensky â€” to bring the news to the Ukrainians. Waltz said that Ukrainian Ambassador Oksana Markarova was â€œpractically in tearsâ€ as the delegation sat waiting, but that Zelensky was still argumentative.

Waltz said that he told Zelensky, â€œLook, Mr. President, time is not on your side here. Time is not on your side on the battlefield. Time is not on your side in terms of the world situation and most importantly, U.S. aid and the taxpayers, tolerance is not unlimited.â€

The national security adviser said that Zelensky â€œhas not gotten the memo that this is a new sheriff in town.â€

Advertisement

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina), who just last year rebuked Vanceâ€™s position on Ukraine and urged the then-senator to take a trip to the war-torn country before taking a position, said during a Fox News interview on Friday after the spat that Zelensky would have to â€œfundamentally change or go.â€ But Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) was the rare GOP official who denounced Trump in a post on X for â€œwalking away from our allies and embracing Putin, a threat to democracy and U.S. values around the world.â€

Zelensky traveled to London on Saturday to meet Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who convened a summit Sunday with other European leaders who have rallied behind the Ukrainian leader.

On Saturday, Rutte, the NATO secretary general, who is expected to attend the summit, described the meeting as â€œunfortunate,â€ but said he made clear to Zelensky that it was important to â€œfind a way to restore his relationshipâ€ with Trump and others in the administration. Pressed in a BBC interview on whether allies could replace U.S. aid for Ukraine, Rutte demurred.

â€œIt is crucial that we stay all in this together,â€ he said. â€œWe have to move beyond what happened.â€
title: How the Trump-Zelensky Oval Office meeting spiraled into chaos

text:
Phil Salt came up with a heartwarming gesture as he guarded a mascot boy from fireworks when the players were walking out for the national anthem at the start of the SA vs ENG match in ICC Champions Trophy 2025 in Karachi on March 1. The boy was scared of the fireworks, which went off and the England national cricket team star noticed that and put his hand covering the boy's face. The video of the England wicketkeeper-batter's adorable gesture has gone viral on social media. England have a forgettable ICC Champions Trophy 2025 campaign. RCB Funny Memes and Jokes Go Viral After Phil Salt, Liam Livingstone Fall for Low Scores in SA vs ENG ICC Champions Trophy 2025 Match.
Phil Salt Guards Mascot Boy from Fireworks
View this post on Instagram A post shared by ICC (@icc)
(SocialLY brings you all the latest breaking news, viral trends and information from social media world, including Twitter (X), Instagram and Youtube. The above post is embeded directly from the user's social media account and LatestLY Staff may not have modified or edited the content body. title: Phil Salt Guards Mascot Boy From Fireworks As Players Walk Out for National Anthem During SA vs ENG ICC Champions Trophy 2025, Video Goes Viral
description:
The England wicketkeeper-batter's heartwarming gesture was shared by the ICC on social media. Phil Salt had a poor time with the bat in hand in the ICC Champions Trophy 2025.

text:
Tonight: Turning cold quickly. Winds from the northwest continue to gust 30 to 45 mph this evening with wind chills falling into the 20s. Overnight lows plunge to the upper teens to mid-20s with some gusts still near 20 to 30 mph under mainly clear skies. Confidence: High

Tomorrow (Sunday): Sun and moderating breezes, though still some morning gusts of 20 to 30 mph as wind chills start in the teens. Wintry afternoon highs in the upper 30s to low 40s feel a few degrees colder with a lighter but lingering breeze. Confidence: High

Tomorrow night: Mostly clear and nearly calm is a recipe for a potentially large range of lows, from the mid-teens in the colder suburbs to the mid-20s downtown. Confidence: Medium-High

A look ahead

Mainly clear Monday with light winds. Still quite chilly with morning temperatures rising through the 20s and 30s. Afternoon highs aim for the mid-40s, then back down to Monday night lows in the upper 20s to low 30s. Confidence: Medium-High

High pressure is in control Tuesday. Temperatures trend noticeably warmer with highs in the mid- to upper 50s, which should feel nice in the sun. Tuesday night lows in the mid-40s to low 50s with a chance of showers overnight. Confidence: Medium
title: CWG Live updates Still gusty this evening ahead of a wintry chill on Sunday
